liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some sad news out of Italy this morning — a man has been crushed to death under thousands of wheels of a Parmesan-style hard cheese weighing about 40 kilograms each. Giacomo Chiapparini, 74, was buried under the cheeses when a shelf broke in his warehouse in the northern Lombardy region creating a domino effect which brought down thousands of wheels, firefighter Antonio Dusi from Bergamo tells AFP. It reportedly took 12 hours for rescuers to move the cheeses and wheels by hand to finally find Chiapparini. The warehouse, located in the small town of Romano di Lombardia near Bergamo, contained a total of 25,000 wheels of Grana Padano.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Italian man crushed to death by 40kg wheels of cheese

props.alt: Four men standing and smiling in a factory, one is a grandfather, one is a son and two others are grandsons. The son is holding a young baby.

children.content: Giacomo Chiapparini (left) with his son, Tiziano, and grandchildren Michael and Gabriel.
(Grana Padano)
Some sad news out of Italy this morning — a man has been crushed to death under thousands of wheels of a Parmesan-style hard cheese weighing about 40 kilograms each.
Giacomo Chiapparini, 74, was buried under the cheeses when a shelf broke in his warehouse
in the northern Lombardy region creating a domino effect which brought down thousands of wheels, firefighter Antonio Dusi from Bergamo tells AFP.
It reportedly took 12 hours for rescuers to move the cheeses and wheels by hand to finally find Chiapparini.
The warehouse, located in the small town of Romano di Lombardia near Bergamo, contained a total of 25,000 wheels of Grana Padano.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian police arrested almost 160 people as part of a national crackdown on outlaw motorcycle gangs, which ran for a week and ended on Sunday. AAP reports that the country-wide operation, dubbed Taskforce Morpheus, led to almost 700 charges and seized 43 firearms, along with more than 20 other weapons, 11 vehicles and hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash. Officers also seized various quantities of different drugs during more than 70 raids across the country. "The success of this week of action should serve as a fresh warning to OMCG [outlaw motorcycle gang] members in Australia and those seeking to hideout offshore," national Taskforce Morpheus chair Detective Superintendent Anthony Conway says. "There is nowhere to run, and there is nowhere to hide."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Latest bikie crackdown leads to almost 700 charges

children.content: Australian police arrested almost 160 people as part of a national crackdown on outlaw motorcycle gangs, which ran for a week and ended on Sunday.
AAP reports that the country-wide operation, dubbed Taskforce Morpheus, led to
almost 700 charges and seized 43 firearms, along with more than 20 other weapons, 11 vehicles and hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash
Officers also seized various quantities of different drugs during more than 70 raids across the country.

props.alt: A pile of around a dozen guns lined up on the ground outside next to a garage door

children.content: (Supplied: ABF)

"The success of this week of action should serve as a fresh warning to OMCG [outlaw motorcycle gang] members in Australia and those seeking to hideout offshore," national Taskforce Morpheus chair Detective Superintendent Anthony Conway says.
"There is nowhere to run, and there is nowhere to hide."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC There’s been a small development in Donald Trump's court case here in Washington DC. If you were following the news last week, you'd know Trump was indicted on conspiracy charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election result. After last week's court appearance, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!" That threatening post prompted prosecutors to respond with a late-night court application to have the former president prevented from going too far with his social posts. In particular, prosecutors raised concerns Trump could publicly reveal confidential material that they will need to give his legal team as part of the court process. They asked the court to issue a "protective order" that would restrict any sharing of that material to a select group of people with a direct stake in the case. A short time ago, Trump's legal team formally responded to the prosecution's request, asking the court to narrow the proposed order "to shield only genuinely sensitive materials from public view". It says the prosecutors' request represents an attempt by the government to limit Trump's First Amendment free speech rights. "Worse, it does this against this administration's primary political opponent, during an election season in which the administration, prominent party members, and media allies have campaigned on the indictment," the response lodged with the court says. The court is yet to decide on the application.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prosecutors are attempting to limit Trump's posting about his indictment

children.content: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC
There’s been a small development in Donald Trump's court case here in Washington DC.
If you were following the news last week, you'd know Trump was indicted on conspiracy charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election result.
After last week's court appearance, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!"
That threatening post prompted prosecutors to respond with a late-night court application
to have the former president prevented from going too far with his social posts.

props.alt: Donald Trump speaking at a lecturn in a suit and tie

children.content: (AP: Artie Walker Jr.)
In particular,
prosecutors raised concerns Trump could publicly reveal confidential material
that they will need to give his legal team as part of the court process.
They asked the court to issue a "protective order" that would restrict any sharing of that material to a select group of people with a direct stake in the case.
A short time ago, Trump's legal team formally responded to the prosecution's request, asking the court to
narrow the proposed order
"to shield only genuinely sensitive materials from public view".
It says the prosecutors' request represents an attempt by the government to limit Trump's First Amendment free speech rights.

"Worse, it does this against this administration's primary political opponent, during an election season in which the administration, prominent party members, and media allies have campaigned on the indictment," the response lodged with the court says.
The court is yet to decide on the application.

title.children: Elon Musk successor steps down from Tesla, ASX gains after Wall Street rally ahead of inflation report

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The National Australia Bank says business confidence has lifted slightly to be back in positive territory in July. However it is still low at 2 index points. Business conditions eased 1 point to 10 index points. Trading conditions, employment and profitability were all steady according to NAB chief economist Alan Oster. “Business conditions continued to show resilience in July and have been broadly steady in the past couple of months at above-average levels," he says. “Business confidence also picked up in July to be back in positive territory as well, although confidence remains low.” However, forward orders remain in negative territory, dragged down by the retail sector, and costs continue to rise for companies including for electricity and wages. “Labour cost growth rose sharply in July, likely reflecting wage rises taking effect on July 1 including minimum and award wage changes,” said Mr Oster. “Labour cost growth was strongest in recreation & personal services, transport & utilities, and retail, which aligns with where we would expect minimum and award wage workers to be most common.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business confidence picks up even though costs rise

children.content: The National Australia Bank says business confidence has lifted slightly to be back in positive territory
in July.
However it is still low at 2 index points.
Business conditions eased 1 point to 10 index points.

props.alt: Table and graph showing business conditions and confidence

children.content: NAB business survey
(NAB)
Trading conditions, employment and profitability were all steady according to
NAB chief economist Alan Oster.
“Business conditions continued to show resilience in July and have been broadly steady in the past couple of months at above-average levels," he says.
“Business confidence also picked up in July to be back in positive territory as well, although confidence remains low.”
However, forward orders remain in negative territory, dragged down by the retail sector, and costs continue to rise for companies including for electricity and wages.
“Labour cost growth rose sharply in July, likely reflecting wage rises taking effect on July 1 including minimum and award wage changes,” said Mr Oster.
“Labour cost growth was strongest in recreation
personal services, transport
utilities, and retail, which aligns with where we would expect minimum and award wage workers to be most common.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumer confidence remains deeply in pessimistic territory amid high interest rates, high inflation and the slowing economy. Westpac and the Melbourne Institute says consumer sentiment dropped 0.4 per cent to 81 in August. A figure below 100 shows there are more pessimists than optimists. Westpac senior economist Matthew Hassan says the Reserve Bank interest rate pauses last month and this month have done little to lift confidence, probably because the RBA has warned that more rate rises may be needed. "The August survey detail pointed to little or no impact from the RBA’s decision to pause. " "Responses showed no improvement over the course of survey week, sentiment instead declining 4.9 per cent between those surveyed prior to the RBA decision and those surveyed after." "The sub-group detail also continued to show a disappointing reaction from the mortgage belt – sentiment amongst consumers with a mortgage down 7.2 per cent in the August month and, 0.8 per cent below its June level despite the two-month pause." "Most consumers are still bracing for further rate rises with over two-thirds of those surveyed after the RBA decision expecting rates to move higher over the year ahead, nearly half of this group expecting a rise of over 1 percentage point." He says consumers are worried about inflation, including recent fuel and energy price rises, with pressure on family finances and concerns about rates and the economic outlook.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence falls

children.content: Consumer confidence remains deeply in pessimistic territory amid high interest rates, high inflation and the slowing economy.
Westpac and the Melbourne Institute says consumer sentiment dropped 0.4 per cent to 81 in August.
A figure below 100 shows there are more pessimists than optimists.
Westpac senior economist Matthew Hassan
says the Reserve Bank interest rate pauses last month and this month have done little to lift confidence, probably because the RBA has warned that more rate rises may be needed.
"The August survey detail pointed to little or no impact from the RBA’s decision to pause. "
"Responses showed no improvement over the course of survey week, sentiment instead declining 4.9 per cent between those surveyed prior to the RBA decision and those surveyed after."

"The sub-group detail also continued to show a disappointing reaction from the mortgage belt – sentiment amongst consumers with a mortgage down 7.2 per cent in the August month and, 0.8 per cent below its June level despite the two-month pause."

"Most consumers are still bracing for further rate rises with over two-thirds of those surveyed after the RBA decision expecting rates to move higher over the year ahead, nearly half of this group expecting a rise of over 1 percentage point."
He says consumers are worried about inflation, including recent fuel and energy price rises, with pressure on family finances and concerns about rates and the economic outlook.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened higher after a rebound on Wall Street. The ASX 200 index has put on 0.3 per cent. Miners and banks have edged up, but most sectors are in the red so far including healthcare stocks. Spot gold fell on concerns of further interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve and iron ore prices dropped amid further cuts in steel production by China. Oil prices were also caught up in the selling after last week's highs on reduced supply. ASX 200 best and worst performers: James Hardie: +14.6% after seeing underlying profit grow over the first quarter. Lake Resources: +5.7% Domain: +2.6% Coronado Global Resources: -11.7% after net profit slumped by two-thirds for the half year to $199 million. Charter Hall: -3.5% Sayona Mining: -3.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher

children.content: The Australian share market has opened higher after a rebound on Wall Street.
The ASX 200 index has put on 0.3 per cent.
Miners and banks have edged up, but most sectors are in the red so far including healthcare stocks.
Spot gold fell on concerns of further interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve and iron ore prices dropped amid further cuts in steel production by China.
Oil prices were also caught up in the selling after last week's highs on reduced supply.
ASX 200 best and worst performers:
James Hardie: +14.6% after seeing underlying profit grow over the first quarter.
Lake Resources: +5.7%
Domain: +2.6%
Coronado Global Resources: -11.7% after net profit slumped by two-thirds for the half year to $199 million.
Charter Hall: -3.5%
Sayona Mining: -3.3%
